Graphical abstract This review focuses on recent advances in the synthesis and application of high entropy alloy electrocatalysts, and current challenges and potential solutions are also discussed. Compared to traditional pure metals or alloys based on just one principal element, high entropy alloys (HEAs) exhibit notable structural and physical characteristics, drawing significant attention. While significant advancements have been made in the synthesis and utilization of HEAs, there is a lack of comprehensive understanding and systematic approach towards the rational design of electrocatalysts. This review begins by introducing the fundamental principles and impacts of HEAs, followed by an overview of traditional and emerging synthesis techniques; in particular, we categorize and critically analyze approaches. Subsequently, a detailed examination of the advancements and comparative performance of HEAs in specific electrocatalytic reactions is presented. The paper concludes by outlining the current challenges and opportunities associated with HEAs catalysts, along with offering personal insights on potential future developments. Keywords High entropy alloys Electrocatalysis Synthesis strategies Energy conversion reactions 1 Introduction The first metals used by humans were close to pure copper obtained from mining and smelting back to 7000 BCE, and iron from meteorites back to 3500 BCE. To improve its mechanical properties, at around 2000 BCE, copper started to be alloyed with tin or lead to produce bronze, the earliest engineered alloy [1,2]. Alloying increased copper's hardness but decreased its toughness, already highlighting the challenge of enhancing one attribute without compromising other advantages [3,4]. These initial alloys and all those developed and extensively used until the 21st century have been based on one or two principal elements with small amounts of secondary components. In 2004, the concept of high entropy alloys (HEAs) was proposed in two independent works by Yeh [5] and Cantor [6]. Since then, HEAs have received increasing interest owing to their immense compositional versatility and their unique physical, chemical, and mechanical properties [7–9]. Especially in the last five years, the synthesis of HEAs with controlled properties and their use in the field of eletrocatalysis have achieved remarkable advances (Fig. 1 ) [10–21]. HEAs are solid solutions composed of at least five elements with equal or nearly equal ratios, typically ranging from 5% to 35% of each component. From a thermodynamics point of view, HEAs are defined as solid solutions stabilized by a high mixing entropy (ΔS mix) that overcomes the enthalpic contribution (ΔH mix) to the total Gibbs free energy (ΔG mix), thus stabilizing the solid solution in front of the formation of intermetallic phases. (1) Δ G mix = Δ H mix - T Δ S mix The configurational entropy change per mole during the formation of a solid solution of n elements can be estimated as the configurational entropy of mixing (Fig. 2 a) [22,23]. (2) Δ S mix = - R Σ c i In c i where R is the gas constant and c i is the mole fraction of the ith component. Using the mixing entropy value, we can classify alloys into different groups: (i) ultra-pure materials with only one element (ΔS mix = 0); (ii) low entropy alloys with one or two principal elements, i.e. traditional alloys (ΔS mix < 0.69R); (iii) medium entropy alloys containing 2–4 main components (0.69 ≤ ΔS mix ≤ 1.61R); (iv) HEAs containing at least 5 principal elements (ΔS mix > 1.61R). HEAs offer multiple degrees of freedom to tune composition and optimize the properties for a range of applications. They have raised particular interest as structural materials because of their excellent mechanical characteristics. More recently, it has been realized that HEAs can play a fundamental role in the transition to renewable energy sources by contributing to the feasibility of several fundamental energy technologies based on electrochemical processes. Two centuries after the industrial revolution, based on the extensive use of fossil fuels as energy sources and chemical reactants, we have altered the Earth’s climate and created a growing environmental problem [24,25]. In this context, the development of cost-effective electrochemical technologies for the conversion and storage of renewable energies, including water electrolyzers [26,27], fuel cells [28,29], metal-air/sulfur batteries [30–33], and carbon/nitrogen cycle [34–37] have become a priority. These technologies are heavily reliant on electrocatalytic processes. At present, the catalysts at the core of these technologies rely on noble metals whose scarcity and high cost jeopardize their economic feasibility [38,39]. As visually shown in the popular volcano diagrams established according to Sabatier's principle among other theories, the very limited possibilities of single metal catalysts impede optimizing the performance parameters [40–43]. Alloying offers additional degrees of freedom to adjust electronic and geometric states of active metals [44–46]. HEAs represent the extreme case in this direction, offering a virtually unlimited number of possibilities to design and engineer catalysts with maximized activity, selectivity, and stability, potentially using low-cost materials or minimizing the use of noble metals [17,47–49]. The distinctive design concept of HEAs materials fosters the generation of numerous catalytically active sites, thereby overcoming the existing constraints on the correlation between catalyst structure and activity [50,51]. In addition to the extensive tunability provided by controlling composition, the exceptional catalytic properties of HEAs have been attributed to four core effects, as illustrated in Fig. 2(b): the high entropy effect in thermodynamics, the severe lattice distortion effect in structure, the sluggish diffusion effect in dynamics, and the “cocktail” effect in performance [52,53]. A first effect is the so-called high entropy effect and it is generally associated with a higher stability of the solid solution in front of the formation of ordered intermetallic phases [54,55]. Moreover, the high entropy inherent in HEAs, characterized by a random atomic distribution, is linked to a diverse array of catalytic sites [56]. Theoretically, HEA nanocrystals consisting of a minimum of five elements possess a vast chemical space and adjustability. The intricate atomic arrangements resulting from the random combination of multiple elements create numerous adsorption sites and nearly continuous patterns of binding energy distribution [57,58]. HEAs are generally characterized by highly defective structures and large lattice distortions caused by the random distribution of atoms with different atomic sizes and electronegativities [59]. This lattice distortion has associated significant strain energy that can increase the catalytic site reactivity and change adsorption energies. In the particular case of water electrolysis, the strain caused by lattice distortions weakens the hydrogen binding energy favoring activity [60,61]. At the same time, the variety of lattice distortions introduces additional diversity to the surface site configurations. In principle, the degree of lattice distortion can be tuned by the proper selection of the HEA components and also by the particle architecture, and in this way, the activity of HEAs can be regulated to maximize performance toward a target reaction [62]. The non-uniform distribution of atoms with varying sizes and electronegativities, along with the resulting lattice distortion, is expected to elevate the activation energy required for atomic diffusion, consequently diminishing the overall diffusion rate of atoms and enhancing the dynamic stability of the catalyst. This phenomenon is commonly referred to as the sluggish diffusion effect [63]. Initially, in the process of atomic diffusion, the likelihood of an atom relocating to a lower-energy site is diminished, reducing the probability of subsequent movement. Conversely, if the atom transitions to a higher-energy site, it may revert back to its initial position, impeding migration [53]. Additionally, the presence of numerous constituent elements in HEAs results in varying diffusion rates for each element. The collective diffusion behavior at a macroscopic level is contingent upon the synchronized movement of a diverse array of elements, thereby, elements with sluggish diffusion rates significantly constrain the overall diffusion rate [64]. The above results show that the distortion of lattice stress field hinders atomic motion and the synergistic diffusion among multiple component elements jointly inhibit the effective diffusion rate. The sluggish diffusion effect delays the nucleation and growth of precipitated phase, resulting in the formation of many nanocrystalline and amorphous phases of HEAs [65], which improves the strength and corrosion resistance of HEAs [22,66]. HEAs are formed by the mixing of many elements but their properties are not a simple superposition of the properties of several elements. The properties of each component element within the alloy will be affected by the presence of the other elements and thus overall new properties can be obtained. This synergistic effect is found on all kinds of alloys, but it is considered to be accentuated when mixing several principal elements within HEAs, where it is known as the “cocktail” effect [67,68]. In order to enhance the development of HEAs, a comprehensive understanding of their properties is essential. To achieve this, we have attempted to categorize HEAs based on their morphological characteristics and phase structure. It is important to note that varying application scenarios necessitate specific material morphologies. Furthermore, the morphology of a catalyst directly impacts its electrochemical activity. By strategically designing the morphology of the catalyst, researchers can optimize its catalytic performance, enhance its efficiency under high current conditions, and minimize the use of precious metals [48,58,69]. As depicted in Fig. 2(c), HEAs are primarily categorized into various dimensional nanoclusters, quantum dots, nanowires, nanosheets, and porous structures. The incorporation of multiple principal elements results in elevated mixing entropy, promoting improved miscibility among elements and hindering the development of intermetallic compounds or ordered phases. Consequently, HEAs have a propensity to adopt straightforward solid solution structures [70,71]. Typical HEAs include face-centered cubic (FCC), body-centered cubic (BCC), hexagonal close-packed (HCP) solid solution phase and amorphous phase (Fig. 2d). At present, the research on phase structure mainly focuses on its effect on mechanical properties [72,73], and there are few studies on how phase structure affects electrocatalytic properties. Over the past ten years, there has been significant advancement in the design of HEAs and their utilization in electrocatalysis [74–78]. Numerous reviews have been published summarizing these developments, although many have focused on specific aspects such as the structural diversity of HEAs, preparation techniques, or applications [79–81]. The increasing use of electrocatalysis in environmental management and energy conversion is of paramount importance for advancing sustainable development. The intricate composition of HEAs, diverse synthesis techniques, and synergistic effects resulting from the presence of multiple elements pose challenges in comprehensively understanding HEA electrocatalysts. The key to maximizing the application potential of HEAs lies in the rational design of target catalysts and the flexible utilization of the four core effects in practical reactions. Furthermore, the rapid and accelerated growth of the HEA field underscores the importance of regularly summarizing the latest research advancements. This review article provides an overview of classical methods for synthesizing HEAs, followed by an examination of their application and catalytic performance in electrocatalysis. The article also discusses the manifestation of the four core effects of HEAs in different applications. Furthermore, it addresses the challenges and prospects in designing and implementing HEA electrocatalysts, exploring potential research directions and solutions to overcome current limitations in the field (Fig. 3 ). 2 HEA synthesis approaches HEAs have been generally produced as bulk solids using high-temperature processes or mechanical alloying techniques. In recent times, innovative approaches have emerged to manufacture nanostructured HEAs at a lower cost and to effectively utilize them in electrocatalytic applications. Nevertheless, the intricate nature of elemental composition and the preparation process still pose significant obstacles to the large-scale synthesis of nanoscale HEAs materials. Consequently, there is a pressing need to devote further attention to the development of preparation processes that can effectively and precisely control the material structural and chemical parameters while at the same time ensuring reproducibility, scalability, negligible environmental impact, and cost-effectiveness. 2.1 Thermal shock Traditional alloying guideline (Hume-Rothery rule) limit the possible combinations of elements with different atomic sizes and crystal structures [68,82], which poses a challenge to the flexible combination of elements in HEAs. Fortunately, recent case studies show the advantage of carbon thermal shock (CTS) technology in avoiding phase separation [83]. CTS technology is an emerging catalyst synthesis strategy that relies on the short current pulse to heat for a very short time a precursor mixture. The resulting ultra-fast heating and cooling allows all metal precursors to be reduced simultaneously, and subsequent rapid cooling ensures that the structure and composition of the sample remain unchanged. Due to its precise heating control, extremely high heating efficiency, and fast reaction, CTS can meet the design requirements of multiple target catalysts, especially in terms of size and composition control [84,85]. In theory, the controlled integration of a variety of elements with very different parameters should increase the range of properties achieved [86–88]. However, due to large parameter differences between the elements, the synthesis of HEA NPs is extremely challenging and frequently additional phases are generated [89–94]. To overcome this limitation, Hu et al. [95] synthesized HEA NPs with uniform composition using a CTS method. As displayed in Fig. 4 (a and b), the precursors of various mixed metal salts were loaded onto the carbon nanofibers that were sharply heated to high temperatures and subsequently cooled. At high temperatures, the metal salts quickly decompose to form liquid metal, which is mixed evenly. The subsequent rapid cooling freezes the homogeneous mixture as no time is given to elements to segregate (Fig. 4c and d). In addition, the chemical composition, size, and phase composition (solid solution or phase separation) of NPs/bulk materials can be well controlled by adjusting the parameters of the CTS method, including temperature, treatment time, rising and cooling rate, etc. Similarly, Yao et al. [96] used non-noble metal HEA (e.g. FeCoNiCu or FeCoNiCrMn) NPs to disperse and stabilize surface noble metal clusters (e.g., Pt or Ir) to form novel isomeric HEA catalysts (HEA@Pt or HEA-5@Ir). As shown in Fig. 4(e and f), first, various metal precursor solutions were added to the substrate (carbonized wood), and then a high-temperature shock was carried out in an Ar environment with a high current pulse to obtain HEA particles (FeCoNiCu). Finally, the HEA particles are soaked in H2PtCl6 solution, the HEA@Pt sample was obtained by galvanic displacement. To verify the universality of the method, the researchers replaced different carbon substrates, such as carbon wood (CW, Fig. 4g and h), carbon paper (CP, Fig. 4i), and carbon nanofibers (CNF, Fig. 4j) to obtain the expected HEA@Pt samples, with Pt clusters uniformly embedded on the HEA surface. Such heterogeneous HEA designs significantly reduce the amount of noble metals, fully expose the noble metal active site, and take advantage of the multi-component coordination and good structural stability provided by the HEA supports, which is expected to achieve high catalytic activity, good structural stability, and noble metal amount reduction. Both studies share common synthesis conditions, including the requirement of a carbon substrate containing metal precursors, an inert argon gas environment, the application of an electric current pulse for heat generation, and rapid heating and cooling to inhibit atomic diffusion. In the liquid state, the atoms within the alloy exhibit rapid movement and random organization. Gradual cooling allows for atomic rearrangement, resulting in the formation of distinct phases as the alloy solidifies. Conversely, rapid cooling (quenching) of the alloy is more likely to result in the retention of a solid solution. Despite the significant reduction in preparation time, the utilization of carbon materials as current supports restricts the widespread adoption of this method. In contrast to conventional heating techniques, the utilization of Joule heating in CTS directly impacts the carbon supports, leading to an enhanced heat utilization rate. Nevertheless, the efficiency of Joule heating is significantly influenced by the quality of the carbon material, underscoring the challenges associated with the preparation of large-scale HEAs materials. In addressing this issue, Hu et al. [97] introduced a microwave heating method that is both efficient and scalable, enabling the synthesis of HEA-NPs on diverse carbon substrates (Fig. 5 a and b). This rapid high-temperature heating process, which can reach temperatures of >1400 K in seconds, when combined with the roll-to-roll process, it provides a viable pathway for scalable HEAs manufacturing (Fig. 5c). In another solution, Choi et al. [98] proposed a photo-thermal synthesis method for HEAs that is compatible with ambient air and has no special requirements for the substrate material. Taking carbon nanofibers (CNFs) as an example, a flash-thermal shock (FTS) lamping can induce instantaneous high-temperature annealing (>1800 °C within 20 ms, Fig. 5d), and has good large-scale synthesis compatibility (6.0 × 6.0 cm2 CNFs paper, Fig. 5e–g). 2.2 Wet chemical methods Some advanced techniques for synthesizing HEAs, such as magnetron sputtering [99,100], arc melting [101,102], and plasma sintering [103,104], necessitate either elevated temperatures or costly low-yield equipment, thereby significantly augmenting the production costs. Conversely, conventional wet chemical methods offer the benefits of high throughput potential, a high level of control over material parameters, and moderate equipment investment, rendering them very appealing for HEA production [105,106]. Li et al. [47] employed a two-step approach to prepare HEA nanoparticles (NPs) with a single-phase structure (Fig. 6 a and b). During a first liquid-phase reaction, the strong reducing agent sodium tetrahydridoborate (NaH4B) is utilized to reduce the high electronegativity elements, such as platinum (Pt), to form rich-Pt cores. Afterwards, unaltered elements create shapeless nanosheets that encase the concentrated-Pt cores. Through heat treatment, the metal elements slowly spread into the concentrated-Pt cores. In another study, Cabot et al. [107] synthesized HEA nanocrystals with a FCC structure through a low-temperature colloidal method using acetates as metal precursors (Fig. 6c and d). The synthesis involved heating a mixed solution in an oxygen-free argon protective atmosphere to achieve simultaneous reduction of multiple metal salts. The solvent and reducing agent used was oleamine (OAm), with glucose serving as an additional reducing agent and (1-hexadecyl)trimethylammonium (CTAC) acting as a surfactant. The CrMnFeCoNi HEAs exhibit a wealth of defects, such as lattice distortions and dislocations (Fig. 6e and f). As noted above, HEA complex compositions promote electrocatalytic activity and stability [108,109]. In addition, the electrode and catalyst particle architecture can play a major role in enhancing the activity of the catalyst by minimizing the reactant paths, maximizing the active site exposure, and improving the utilization rate of noble metal atoms [110,111]. In this context, hollow nanoparticle architectures can be advantageous. However, due to the harsh preparation conditions and complex composition, the effective preparation of hollow HEAs remains a major challenge. Based on their previous works [112,113], Hu et al. [114] synthesized hollow PdCuMoNiCo HEA particles using a one-pot solvothermal method with the help of removable ligands (glutamate) and hybrid carbon (reduced graphene oxide and carbon nanotubes) (Fig. 7 a and b). It can be seen in Fig. 7(c–e) that lattice distortion occurs in the Pd shell due to the difference in the atomic diameter of elements. Combining XRD and XPS analysis (Fig. 7f–i), it was found that the construction of Pd-based HEA can adjust the strain and electronic structure of the active center Pd. The hollow structure of the PdCuMoNiCo HEA not only improves the electrochemical specific surface area (ECSA) of the catalyst but also alleviates the excessive strain changes caused by heteroatoms, that is, the strain of Pd active site can be regulated by both composition (high entropy effect) and structure (hollow structure). In multi-principal element alloys, the metal precursor salts display notable variations in reduction potential and thermal decomposition temperature, leading to difficulties in achieving simultaneous reduction of all metal precursors to produce HEA nanoparticles. This challenge often results in the formation of distinct phases [115]. Additionally, wet chemical methods used in the synthesis process typically necessitate the inclusion of supplementary substances, such as reducing agents and surfactants (as depicted in Fig. 6a and c), which, if not adequately removed, may become incorporated into the final particles [116–118]. In general, wet chemical methods present several advantages for the synthesis of HEAs, however, there remain several significant challenges that require resolution. 2.3 Electrospinning Electrospinning has become one of the most common methods for nanofiber manufacturing. It allows preparing fibers with a diameter of tens to hundreds of nanometers, high porosity, and tuned dimensions and composition [119–121]. Metals can be introduced in the form of precursor salts or NPs in the electrospinned solution. Using electrospinned nanofibers as a reaction template, Wang et al. [122] produced FeCoNiCuMn HEA NPs on the surface of carbon nanofibers (CNFs) after high-temperature carbonization treatment (FeCoNiCuMn HEA/CNFs, Fig. 8 a and b). The results show that the alloy catalyst has a single FCC crystal structure and good crystallinity (Fig. 8c and e), with the five metal elements uniformly distributed in the nanoparticles and with content in between 15% and 25% (Fig. 8d and f). Recently, Zhu et al. [16] used electrospinning technology to synthesize a series of FeCoNiXRu (X: Cu, Cr, Mn) HEAs with different catalytic active sites in carbon nanofibers. As shown in Fig. 8(g), the FeCoNiMnRu HEA was prepared by the two-step method of electrospinning and high-temperature calcination. The molar content of five metal elements was between 10% and 25%, and they were uniformly distributed in the single-phase solid solution. TEM images (Fig. 8h) showed a uniform distribution of FeCoNiMnRu NPs. The lattice fringes shown in Fig. 8(i and j) correspond to the (111) and (200) faces. Furthermore, the fast Fourier transform (FFT) (Fig. 8i) further reveals the FCC crystal structure of FeCoNiMnRu HEA NPs. In-situ XRD demonstrated that the FCC phase of HEA coexists with the Mn3Co7 phase between 800 and 1000 °C (Fig. 8k and l). With the increase in temperature, Mn atoms and Ru atoms gradually diffuse into the FCC lattice. The shift of diffraction peaks reflected a larger lattice distortion caused by different atomic sizes. The extension of calcination time caused the diffraction peak of FCC to shift in the opposite direction, that is, the lattice distortion is gradually eliminated. Electrospinning is often combined with high-temperature carbon reduction to produce HEAs. The electrospinning step usually plays a role in the aggregation of metal precursors, and the subsequent high-temperature carbonization reduces the precursors to HEAs. The HEAs obtained by this method are generally nanoparticles dispersed in the carbon fiber. Thus the carbon fiber plays a fundamental role in dispersing nanoparticles and inhibiting agglomeration, overall improving the catalytic stability of HEAs. 2.4 Template methods Controlling the morphology, composition, and uniformity of HEA-based nanopatterns enables the development of advanced materials for nanoelectronics, nanophotonics, catalysis, and other fields, but there is a lack of a universal method to construct multimetallic patterns [123,124]. With this in mind, Liu et al. [125] report a deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) origami-based metallization reaction system that is capable of generating multimetallic nanopattern materials. Its synthesis principle is as follows: through the strong coordination interaction between metal and DNA, metal ions can accumulate at the protruding clustered DNA (pcDNA) sites of DNA origami and act as the nucleation sites of metals (Fig. 9 a). By this method, a series of multi-metal nanopattern materials were synthesized, with up to 5 metal elements (Co, Pd, Pt, Ag, and Ni) (Fig. 9b). This work is helpful to control the uniform distribution of elements at the nanoscale and contribute to the synthesis of multi-metal nanopattern materials. It is well known that multimetallic alloy nanoparticles show unique advantages in a variety of applications due to the variability of their composition. However, finding a general synthesis strategy remains challenging. Pang et al. [126] used an efficient and versatile two-dimensional (2D) metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) assisted pyrolysis-displacement-alloying (PDA) synthesis route to prepare a series of highly dispersed binary, ternary and HEA NPs. 2D MOF nanosheets serve as templates (Fig. 9c). Fig. 9(d–f) shows the obtained CoRuPtIrRhPd HEAs. These HEA NPs are loaded on the porous nitrogen-doped carbon nanosheets (PNC NSs). These works used MOF nanosheets and DNA origami as templates to aggregate multiple target metals. The final HEAs are obtained by subsequent thermal reduction or chemical reduction. The selected template needs to have a strong interaction with metal ions. 2.5 Dealloying Although the engineering of HEA-based electrocatalysts has made serious progress, the limited number of surface active sites is still the most important factor restricting their electrocatalytic activity [10,127]. As an alternative to producing small particles, to increase surface site exposure compounds with porous architectures can be produced. The dealloying method is one of the most common methods of preparation of nanoporous metals [128,129]. Most porous nano-metals are produced using top-down chemical corrosion dealloying or electrochemical dealloying [130]. Under corrosion conditions, because of the difference in electrochemical behavior between different components in the alloy, the relatively active components will dissolve, while the relatively stable components will be enriched to spontaneously form a disordered nanoporous structure [131]. Song et al. [69] used the synthetic route shown in Fig. 10 (a) to prepare HEAs at the hectogram level. First, various metals are arc-melted to obtain mother ingots. The ingots are then further made into fibers by a melt-extracted process. Finally, the pore structure is introduced by dealloying. Cross-sectional TEM images show a clear core-shell structure (Fig. 10b). The structure and composition of HEAs can be attributed according to the interplanar distance and selected area electron diffraction pattern (SAED) (Fig. 10c and d). The EDS mapping shows that the nanocrystalline oxides are isolated by amorphous HEA interfaces, which provide conductive paths for electron transfer (Fig. 10e). These results confirm that crystalline HEA, as a core, can provide a conductive substrate for the catalytic material in the shell and improve the self-supported ability. This method is shown to be suitable for industrial mass production. Other previous studies have also shown that constructing crystalline-amorphous (c-a) heterostructures is an effective method to increase the density of active sites and accelerate electron transfer between c-a interfaces [132–134]. As noted above, numerous catalytic reactions are strongly dependent on noble metal-based catalysts, but noble metals have limited resources and high prices [135–139]. Developing multi-component nanoscale HEAs is crucial to reduce the use of noble metals and utilize the “cocktail” effect to enhance catalytic activity [68,140–142]. Qiu et al. [14] adopted a dealloying strategy to prepare a series of HEA catalysts (Fig. 10f). Specifically, the Ni, Co, Cu, Mn, and other elements are first melted into the single-phase precursor alloys, and then treated with an acidic solution (1 M (NH4)2SO4) to remove most of the Mn, resulting in a porous HEA/high entropy oxide (Fig. 10g). STEM image revealed ultra-fine nanoscale solid ligaments and further observation revealed that these ligaments contained nanopore structures and extended throughout the sample (Fig. 10h). Similarly, to enhance the intrinsic catalytic activity and cycle life of HEA catalysts, Kang et al. [143] synthesized a nanoporous NiCoFeMoMn HEA employing a synthesis strategy similar to that shown in Fig. 10(f), where electrochemical dealloying was used as the final step. As shown in Fig. 10(i–k), after dealloying, a crack with a width of ∼500 nm was formed on the catalyst surface. Small holes of ∼5 nm are formed in the element non-segregation area. However, no dealloying occurred in the element segregation area, and only ∼40 nm nanopores were formed nearby. Fig. 10(l) displays that Mn, Fe, and a small amount of Co are removed during the alloying process. The multistage pore structure not only increases the active area, but also provides a channel for the ions and electrolytes involved in the electrocatalytic reaction, and is conducive to the desorption of bubbles. 2.6 Other synthesis methods In the engineering of a catalyst, it is necessary to adopt an appropriate synthesis method to prepare the target catalyst according to the requirements of the working environment and reaction. For example, in the application of electrolytic water splitting, Fang et al. [142] used magnetron sputtering to prepare FeCoNiCuPd HEAs film on a conductive substrate, and as a self-supporting electrode material, avoiding the use of binder (Fig. 11 a). Dey et al. [144] prepared Co-Cu-Fe-Ni-Zn HEA films in water medium by pulsed electrodeposition (Fig. 11b). In the anti-corrosion study, Srivastava et al. [145] used electrodeposition to deposit MnFeCoNiCu HEAs coating on a low carbon steel matrix (Fig. 11c). A crucial approach to enhancing the mechanical properties of metals is through the rational design of alloys. Wang et al. [146] successfully synthesized a fine-grain NbMoTaWRe refractory HEA with superior strength and ductility using continuous mechanical alloying and spark plasma sintering (Fig. 11d). The mechanical alloying process typically involves pretreating metal powder through high-energy ball milling, followed by press forming and sintering at elevated temperatures. In contrast to the wet preparation method discussed in Section 2.2, this process offers convenience for industrial applications, mitigating issues associated with excessive utilization of metal salts and organic solvents, as well as minimizing precursor material waste. Nevertheless, it is essential to acknowledge that impurities may be introduced during the high-energy ball mill process due to the ball mill tank and medium. Therefore, employing a compatible ball mill device within a vacuum or inert gas environment is imperative for conducting the ball milling process effectively. In addition, the mechanical method lacks the precise control advantages of the wet chemical method. In contrast to the one-step synthesis method, two-step or multi-step continuous methods may offer a broader and more precise range of control. This is particularly significant in the synthesis of HEAs, where the ability to manipulate morphology and achieve a diverse element composition is crucial for leveraging the advantages of HEAs. However, HEAs present a major synthesis challenge due to the presence of multiple component elements that exhibit significant variations in reduction potential, atomic size, and electronic structure. The existing constraints on structural control and method universality continue to hinder the development of efficient and reliable synthesis methods, such as shock-type and solution-phase syntheses (Fig. 12 b and c) [147–150]. These limitations can be addressed through the segregation of morphology control and composition control. Huang et al. [151] prepared a range of HEAs with controllable morphology using template-directed synthesis (Fig. 12a). Initially, low-element alloys with diverse structures were prepared via a one-pot wet chemistry method. Subsequently, these alloys were utilized as seeds for the synthesis of multi-element HER NPs employing a template method. The presence of multi-element atoms with significantly different atomic radii resulted in the acquisition of numerous lattice distortions within the sample material (Fig. 12d and e). Similarly, Wen et al. [152] initially produced a MOF on carbon cloth (CC) through a solvothermal reaction. Subsequently, the MOF was subjected to sintering in a reducing atmosphere, resulting in the formation of CoNiCuMnMo HEA NPs as depicted in Fig. 12(f). The utilization of a MOF precursor facilitated the homogeneous blending of multiple metals, while the subsequent pyrolysis process led to the formation of metal nanoparticles enveloped by a carbon layer (Fig. 12g). It is the cornerstone of the application of HEAs in the field of electrocatalysis to explore a simple, controllable, moderate cost and wide adaptability preparation method. As shown above, through the review of the current classic cases of synthetic HEAs, the preparation methods of HEAs can be divided into four types, as listed in Table 1 . (1) Shock synthesis, the metal particles are dispersed on the carrier by ultra-fast quenching [96,153]; (2) chemical methods with bottom-up technique, a variety of metal salt precursors are usually dissolved and mixed, and reduced by high temperature, reducing agents [47,154], etc.; (3) top-down technique, using ball milling [146,155], sputtering [156], etc. to break the bulk precursor materials to obtain HEAs, and the whole preparation process does not involve liquid solvents; (4) the fourth is a multi-step process, such as ball milling coupled with dealloying method [157]. Finally, it should be pointed out that a lot of current work is focused on performance development, while the work and theory of synthesis processes are relatively weak. The development of mature and feasible preparation process is the key issue to promote the industrial application of HEAs. 3 Electrocatalytic application of HEAs HEAs exhibit high temperature resistance, corrosion resistance, and high mechanical strength, making them ideal for the production of high-performance tools and molds [158,159]. Conversely, the prevailing themes of contemporary global development are energy and environmental concerns. Electrocatalysis has emerged as a highly efficient solution for addressing issues related to energy supply, chemical synthesis, and environmental remediation, thus representing a current research focus and area of interest. The value of HEAs containing five or more elements lies in their expansive compositional space, which allows for precise tuning of surface electronic structure and adsorption energies of reactants and intermediates. This flexibility enables the optimization of activity and selectivity in specific reactions, potentially achieving near-continuous distribution of adsorption energies [10,56,160]. Hence, HEAs exhibit significant potential for use in heterogeneous catalytic reactions and multi-product reactions, including but not limited to the electrolysis of water, fuel cells, CO2RR, and electrocatalytic synthesis of ammonia. In the following sections, we examine recent case studies involving HEAs as electrocatalysts and investigate the origins of their exceptional properties. 3.1 Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) The primary method for generating green hydrogen is through water electrolysis with renewable energy sources [161,162], which encompasses two electrochemical reactions: the cathodic HER and the anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [163–166]. Many contemporary catalysts used in water electrolysis necessitate high overpotentials in non-acidic electrolytes to attain industrial current densities, primarily due to sluggish kinetics and intricate reaction intermediates [167–171]. Enhancing the catalytic efficiency can be achieved through the rational design of catalyst structures to increase the quantity of exposed active sites, and the electronic modulation to enhance the intrinsic activity of these sites [172]. To effectively rival hydrogen produced from fossil fuels, green hydrogen necessitates economically viable electrode materials with high performance. Lang's research group [173] reported the application of self-supported nanoporous NiFeCoCuTi HEAs in-situ synthesized on Ni foam. The columnar nanostructure of 3D interconnects facilitates electron/mass transfer in HER (Fig. 13 a and b). At the same time, the electron transfer between different elements regulates the adsorption energy of *H and *OH on the surface of NiFeCoCuTi alloy (Fig. 13c). The self-supported NiFeCoCuTi electrode has excellent alkaline HER, requiring only 209 mV overpotential to drive a 2 A cm−2 current density (Fig. 13d). It can be observed from Fig. 13(e) that Ti element greatly improves HER activity, which is due to the adsorption of *OH by Ti atom, thus forming a multi-site electrocatalytic center on the alloy surface. In summary, nano-porous NiFeCoCuTi HEAs can be used as a potential material for electrolysis cathodes, offering insights for designing multi-site electrocatalytic materials. Mesoporous catalysts are widely utilized in academic research and industrial applications owing to their expansive surface area, numerous active sites, high conductivity, and the ability to tailor their pore structure [174–176]. Yamauchi's team [177] synthesized mesoporous PtPdRhRuCu HEAs using a one-pot wet-chemical reduction method, as illustrated in Fig. 13(f). The presence of numerous mesopores in these alloys facilitates ion migration and enhances the exposure of active sites. The PtPdRhRuCu HEAs exhibited superior catalytic activity for the HER, attributed to both the high entropy effect and the mesoporous structure of the electrode, as depicted in Fig. 13(g). This study confirms the advantages of HEAs over low entropy and medium entropy alloys in electrocatalytic HER applications (Fig. 13h). Nanoporous metals are a kind of functional materials composed of pores interwoven in 3D space. This 3D architecture promotes the transport of ions and electrons, which coupled with a high specific surface area, makes it adequate for electrocatalytic applications [178]. Thin nanosheets have a large surface area, high atomic utilization, and increased exposure to surface metal atoms, which enhances electrocatalytic performance [179–181]. Lattice distortions and defects can accelerate the adsorption and dissociation of species and optimize the intrinsic activity of active sites [182,183]. Multiple elements working together can control the catalyst's electronic structure and d-band center, improving adsorption energy for intermediates at various sites [184,185]. The interaction of different metal components promotes electron transfer due to strong coupling and bonding effects [186,187]. Combining these factors, Wang's team [188] prepared an ultra-thin HEA metallene by a one-step solvothermal method (Fig. 14 a). Fig. 14(b) demonstrates the ultra-thin nature of PdPtRhIrCu metallene, which helps to improve atomic utilization. The prepared PdPtRhIrCu metallene only needs a 15 mV overpotential to achieve efficient hydrogen evolution at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 14c), and its Tafel slope is 37 mV dec−1 (Fig. 14d), showing excellent catalytic activity and kinetics. The DFT calculations further prove that the synergistic effect between the elements in HEAs optimizes the electronic structure and improves the intrinsic activity of the catalyst (Fig. 14e). HEAs with tunable composition, electronic structure, and corrosion resistance have great potential applications in acidic HER. Xia et al. [13] reported the preparation of carbon-supported ultra-small NiCoFePtRh HEA (us-HEA/C) NPs by a chemical co-reduction method. As HER electrocatalyst, NiCoFePtRh has high catalytic activity, and achieves high mass activity of 28.3 A mg−1 (mass based on noble metals) at −0.05 V (vs. RHE) (Fig. 14f). Operando XANES analysis combined with theoretical calculations revealed Rh to be the main active center of us-HEA/C. Nevertheless, the tunable electronic structure and the synergistic effect between the five elements promote the HER (Fig. 14g and h). 3.2 OER The efficiency of electrocatalytic water decomposition is mainly limited by the slow four-electron transfer OER on the anode [189,190]. Noble metal catalysts like RuO2 and IrO2 are effective for OER but their high cost and poor stability restrict their use [191–193]. The synergistic effect between multi-elements within HEAs shows unique advantages in this direction. Fang et al. [194] prepared polymetallic MOF precursors by chemical precipitation and then pyrolyzed them to obtain HEA-based nanocatalysts with metal@carbon core–shell structure (CoNiCuMnAl@C) (Fig. 15 a). Under an alkaline environment (1 M KOH), when CoNiCuMnAl@C reaches 10 mA cm−2, the overpotential is only 215 mV (Fig. 15b). Besides, benefiting from the intrinsic stability brought about by the high entropy effect and the physical protection of the outer carbon shell, CoNiCuMnAl@C demonstrates excellent OER catalytic stability. In-situ Raman characterization revealed a reconstruction phenomenon occurring on the surface of the HEA during the electrocatalytic process, leading to the formation of highly active Ni(Co)OOH species (Fig. 15c and d). DFT calculations showed that Ni(Co)OOH effectively reduces the reaction barrier for the rate-determining step (O* → OOH*) in the OER process and optimizes the electrochemical oxygen evolution kinetics, while Cu/Mn/Al sites can promote the transfer of electrons (Fig. 15e). Proton exchange membrane (PEM) electrolyzers generally offer larger operating current densities than alkaline water electrolyzers (AWE) [195,196]. Furthermore, this technology has a fast start-up and dynamic response speed, which contributes to the stable operation of the equipment. With a wide range of current loads, renewable energy generators can cope better with intermittency and volatility; the compact structure of the device makes it more suitable for mobile and temporary use. PEM has gained rapid popularity as a result of these advantages. If the cost of equipment can be reduced, PEM will become the mainstream for water splitting. However, within PEM electrolyzers, the highly corrosive acidic conditions at high oxidation potential make the development of efficient OER catalysts a great challenge [197–199]. Most OER catalysts with excellent performance under alkaline conditions usually show poor kinetics in acidic media, and serious performance attenuation occurs during operation. The combination of passivation elements and elements with catalytic activity is the key to obtaining both high corrosion resistance and high catalytic activity. Based on this, Mitsuru et al. [200] proposed a method for designing HEAs using only non-precious metal elements (Fig. 15f). The researchers used a top-down approach to synthesize the nonary alloys, and a bottom-up approach to synthesize the quaternary alloys and quinary alloys as a control group. Quasi-in-situ electrochemical XPS (EC-XPS) indicated that the synergistic effect (“cocktail” effect) between Ti, Zr, Nb, and Mo has a significant effect on passivation, while Cr, Ni, and Co participate in the redox process (Fig. 15g–i). DFT calculations showed that Cr, Co, Ni, Mn, and Fe improve the catalytic activity (Fig. 15j). Electrochemical measurements also supported these conclusions (Fig. 15k). The above indicates that the self-selected/reconstructed multi-component alloy has good corrosion resistance under actual PEM conditions. The high entropy mixture enhances stability of the catalyst by forming a single-phase solid solution structure instead of intermetallic compounds, known as the high entropy effect or “cocktail” effect. The activity and stability of the catalyst can be improved by constructing the heterojunction and utilizing its synergistic effect [201,202]. For example, Wang et al. [203] adopted a high-temperature pyrolysis method to synthesize FeCoNiMnCr HEA and high-entropy oxide (HEO) heterocatalysts (FeCoNiMnCr HEA-HEO) by spontaneous reconstruction. The catalyst showed excellent alkaline OER activity and stability, with overpotential as low as 320 mV at 500 mA cm−2 and maintaining 240 h at 100 mA cm−2 (Fig. 16 a and b). Fig. 16(c and d) shows that the formation of HEO breaks the strong overlap effect on 3d orbital and improves the d-band center of the active site; furthermore, the surface of the catalyst has a moderate binding energy to OH* (Fig. 16e), thus enhancing the electrical activity and achieving efficient and durable OER. Similarly, in another study, Cheng et al. [204] developed a sub-2 nm HEA catalyst (HEA@Ir-MEO, Ir0.7Ru0.14Ni0.08Mo0.08O2) composed of Ir-rich medium entropy oxide shell (IrRuNiMoO x ) and IrRuCoNiMo HEA core. The catalyst showed low overpotential and excellent stability under acidic conditions, which provided an efficient catalyst for PEMWE (Fig. 16f and g). A series of characterization analyses can conclude that the transition metal may be doped into the IrO x lattice, lattice distortion and sluggish diffusion effect inhibit the dissolution of the transition metal under acidic conditions, providing good structural stability. DFT calculations show that Ir0.7Ru0.14Ni0.08Mo0.08O2 exhibits a smaller energy barrier (1.75 eV) of rate determining step (RDS) than IrO2 (2.01 eV) (Fig. 16h), and confirmed the transition metal doping can significantly improve the OER activity, it is derived from the HEAs “cocktail” effect. A comprehensive comprehension and judicious utilization of the synergistic effect in HEA materials can significantly aid in the development of targeted catalysts, particularly in intricate, multi-step catalytic reactions. Electrochemically induced surface restructuring readily takes place in OER processes, with numerous transition metal-based catalysts being designated as “pre-catalysts”, and the restructured phase is commonly acknowledged as the true active species [205]. Factors such as elemental dissolution, electrolyte temperature, pH, and coordination environment have been shown to impact the reconstruction of catalysts, particularly in the context of HEAs. While existing research primarily examines the influence of catalyst composition on hydroxyl oxide activity using in-situ techniques, there is a notable lack of studies investigating methods to actively control the surface reconstruction of pre-catalysts, a topic that warrants further exploration [206]. 3.3 Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) The electrocatalytic ORR is essential for a variety of energy conversion applications such as fuel cells and metal-air batteries (4e− ORR, Eqs. (3) and (4)) [207–209]. It also provides a new path for the green and sustainable production of H2O2 (2e− ORR, Eqs. (5) and (7)) [210,211]. It should be noted that expensive Pt-based materials are still the main ORR catalysts, in addition, for 2e− ORR, the formation of H2O2 may lead to catalyst inactivation, equipment corrosion, and some competitive reactions (Eqs. (3) and (4)) or side reactions (Eqs. (6) and (8)) may reduce the efficiency of H2O2 generation [212,213]. The success of these technologies relies on finding highly active, selective and exceedingly durable electrocatalysts at moderate cost to promote the 4e− or 2e− ORR. 4e− ORR: (3) Acidic media: O2 + 4H+ + 4e− → 2H2O (4) Basic media: O2 + 2H2O + 4e− → 4OH− 2e− ORR: (5) Acidic media: O2 + 2H+ + 2e− → H2O2 (6) H2O2 + 2H+ + 2e− → 2H2O (7) Basic media: O2 + H2O + 2e− → HO2 − + OH− (8) HO2 − + H2O + 2e− → 3OH− At present, ORR electrocatalysts rely on Pt which has a high cost and moderate stability [214]. The expense of Pt-based HEA catalysts employed in the ORR remains prohibitively high, while their durability fails to meet practical requirements. Consequently, there is a pressing need to devise HEA catalysts that are both more cost-effective and stable. Fu et al. [215] synthesized PtPdFeCoNi HEA NPs through a high-temperature injection technique, as illustrated in Fig. 17 (a). The random and uniform distribution of all atoms, as depicted in Fig. 17(b and c), enables these nanoparticles to manifest the inherent characteristics of HEA. The ORR half-wave potential of the prepared PtPdFeCoNi HEA/C is as high as 0.920 V (Fig. 17d), and the mass activity and specific activity are as high as 1.23 A mgPt −1 and 1.80 mA cm−2, respectively, which are about 6.2 times and 4.9 times higher than that of commercial Pt/C, improving the utilization rate of precious metal Pt and reducing the material cost (Fig. 17e). As shown in Fig. 17(f), even after 50,000 durability tests, the activity loss is negligible, showing outstanding stability. Pt-based HEA NPs can enhance electrocatalyst performance through high entropy and synergistic effects [216,217]. Li et al. [218] devised an anchoring-carbonization strategy that forms high-entropy Pt alloy nanocrystals (HENs) containing 6 elements less than 3 nm in size while firmly loading them in ordered mesoporous carbon (6-HENs/PC, Fig. 17g). For comparison, low-entropy alloys (containing 2 elements, 2-LENs/PC) and medium-entropy alloys (containing 3/4 elements, 3-MENs/PC, 4-MENs/PC) were synthesized by the same method. The electrocatalytic test showed the highest half-wave potential for 6-HENs/PC, at 0.898 V (Fig. 17h). The mass activity and specific activity of this catalyst were 3.8–6.3 times that of other alloy samples and commercial Pt/C (Fig. 17i). Stability tests showed that after 5000 cycles, 6-HEA/PC maintained nearly 98% of its initial mass activity (Fig. 17j). In order to investigate the enhancement mechanism of HEAs, spectral analysis was conducted. The XRD pattern (Fig. 17k) revealed a notable shift of the Pt(111) peak in 6-HENs/PC towards a higher angle compared to other catalysts, suggesting increased lattice shrinkage and strain within the material. This observation aligns with the lattice distortion characteristic of HEA materials. In the XPS spectra presented in Fig. 17(l), it was observed that the Pt 4f peak of 6-HENs/PC exhibited a notable shift towards lower binding energy, suggesting an increase in electron density surrounding the Pt atoms within the material. These findings suggest that both strain and electronic effects play a significant role in lowering the d-band center of Pt, enhancing the adsorption of oxygenated species at the catalytic active site, and ultimately improving the catalytic performance. The exceptional electrocatalytic durability is due to the high entropy effect and sluggish diffusion of HEAs, as well as the stable interface bonding formed by anchoring-carbonization strategy with porous carbon, preventing migration and aggregation of metal species during ORR. 3.4 Hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR) Hydrogen fuel cells are highly appealing energy conversion devices because of their high efficiency and no pollution [219,220]. Currently, popular fuel cell technologies are mainly divided into proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) and anion exchange membrane fuel cell (AEMFC). PEMFC has the advantages of lightness, high energy conversion and low starting temperature, but its catalyst relies heavily on Pt-based materials [221]. For AEMFC, similar to alkaline HER, the reaction kinetics of alkaline HOR is several orders of magnitude lower than that in acidic [222,223], and it also has the advantage of using cost-effective materials, which has great application prospects. HEA-based catalysts have also attracted attention as HOR catalysts due to their unique physicochemical properties, such as structure-dependent synergistic effects that can improve catalytic activity and durability [224,225]. Huang and others [226] synthesized PtRuNiCoFeMo HEA subnanometer nanowires (SNWs). In Fig. 18 (a–c), it is observed that HEA SNWs have a distorted structure with rich atomic step size and a lattice mismatch rich in defects. The electrochemical test results showed that the mass activity and specific activity of HEA SNWs/C for HOR reached 6.75 A mg−1 Pt+Ru and 8.96 mA cm−2 at an overpotential of 50 mV. The excellent performance was explained by the stable valence state of Co and Ni sites due to nearby Fe and Mo sites, while Pt and Ru sites regulate overall electroactivity for great HOR properties (Fig. 18d and e). The change of the d-band center showed that the adsorption of H by HEA SNWs/C decreased, but was favorable to the adsorption of OH intermediate (Fig. 18f and g). DFT calculations revealed that the interaction between metals in HEA SNWs enhances the catalyst's electronic structure, leading to stronger binding of proton and hydroxyl and increased HOR activity (Fig. 18h). Yu et al. [227] prepared two kinds of HEA NP with disordered structure (d-HEA NPs) and ordered structure (p-HEA NPs) by wet chemical synthesis by regulating nucleation and growth. Geometrical phase analysis (GPA) based on atomic resolution TEM images can be used to analyze the lattice deformation of samples (Fig. 18i–l). The contraction and expansion of lattice deformation in the upper left and lower right of Fig. 18(j and l), which may be due to the redistribution of strain field caused by crystal twins in d-HEA. Different shear deformation fields can be observed in Fig. 18(k), indicating that the material has short-range order. Fig. 18(m) shows that d-HEA has HOR catalytic activity, and the current density can reach 3.4 mA cm−2 when the rotating disk electrode speed is 2500 r min−1, which is close to the theoretical limiting current. Compared with p-HEA and commercial Pt/C, d-HEA showed the best HOR activity (Fig. 18n), which may be due to the electronic structure changes caused by lattice distortion, thus improving the electrocatalytic activity. Further, in the actual H2-O2 proton exchange membrane fuel cell, the fuel cell with d-HEA NPs as the anode has a cell potential of 0.9 V at open circuit, and the power density can reach up to 15.3 kW g−1 of precious metal, which is significantly better than p-HEA (Fig. 18o). 3.5 CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) The CO2RR provides a very atractibve and sustainable way to convert CO2 into chemicals or fuels thus promoting carbon neutrality [228–231]. Nevertheless, the primary obstacles facing the electrocatalytic CO2RR include its competition with the HER and high kinetic barriers, leading to constraints on electrolyte choices, reduced product selectivity, and moderate Faraday efficiency (FE) [232–234]. As in previous technologies, the performance and cost of the CO2RR electrocatalysts are the two most important factors defining the successful application of CO2RR; thus much effort has been invested in recent years in the development of high-performance CO2RR electrocatalysts [235]. However, designing highly active, selective, and affordable CO2RR catalysts still is a big challenge. Copper-based catalysts have attracted much attention because of their notable CO2 conversion efficiency, however, Cu shows limited product selectivity [236–238]. Benefitting from the “cocktail” effect of HEAs, high-efficiency catalysts can be designed by adjusting the composition. On this basis, Biswas et al. [239] synthesized AuAgPtPdCu HEAs with FCC structure containing Cu elements by melting and cryogrinding, and applied them to electrocatalytic CO2RR. Electrochemical tests show that the FE(gas product) of CO2RR can reach 100% at a low applied potential (Fig. 19 a). DFT calculations revealed the reaction mechanism showing that HEAs have a thermodynamic advantage over the Cu(111) surface in the adsorption of *OCH3 and *O intermediates (Fig. 19b). By calculating the HER Gibbs free-energy (ΔG H*), the results show that the HER of AuAgPtPdCu HEAs is thermodynamically unfavorable (Fig. 19c), which means that HER is inhibited to a certain extent. To expose more active sites, it is important to design and develop HEAs with 3D structures. HEA aerogels (HEAAs) combine the advantages of HEAs (synergistic effects and catalytic performance) and aerogels (3D network structure with its large porosity and high specific surface area). Thus HEAAs have great application potential in catalytic reactions [240,241]. Liu et al. [242] prepared a series of highly active and durable HEAAs electrocatalysts for CO2RR by melting and cryogrinding, which prevents oxidation of the sample (Fig. 19d and e). Electrochemical tests show PdCuAuAgBiIn HEAAs can generate C1 products in the range of −0.7 to −1.1 V with FE of almost 100%, and the maximum FEHCOOH at −1.1 V (vs. RHE) is 98.1% (Fig. 19f). PdCuAuAgBiIn HEAAs exhibit superior performance in CO2RR compared to both HEA particles and Pd metallic aerogels. This enhanced performance may be attributed to the robust interaction between various metals and surface unsaturated sites within the HEAAs, which effectively modulates the electronic configuration of the catalyst. Consequently, optimizing the adsorption energy of HCOO*, inhibiting CO poisoning and competitive HER, ultimately leading to improved formic acid production (Fig. 19g and h). 3.6 Nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR)/nitrate reduction reaction (NO3RR) Ammonia (NH3) is an important chemical raw material, especially in fertilizer but also in coatings and other fields, being the second-highest commercial chemical in terms of production volume. NH3 is also a potential hydrogen storage chemical because of its advantages of convenient storage and transportation and high hydrogen content [243]. At present, the Haber-Bosch process accounts for over 90% of NH3 production, necessitating elevated temperature and pressure, substantial energy consumption, and dependence on fossil fuels. Conversely, the electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) exhibits potential as a sustainable method for synthesizing ammonia, offering mild operating conditions [244–246]. However, high overpotentials, low NH3 yield, and poor catalyst stability remain the major challenges for the industrial production of NH3 by NRR. Wang et al. [247] prepared RuFeCoNiCu HEA NPs with small size and uniformity by a liquid phase reduction method, the catalyst was then coated on carbon paper (RuFeCoNiCu/CP) for NRR testing. Fig. 20 (a) shows the stability of the catalyst, after 12 cycles, the yield does not decrease significantly, proving that RuFeCoNiCu/CP has excellent catalytic stability. A large number of theoretical studies have shown that the potential determining step (PDS) in the NRR process is usually the first hydrogenation reaction of *N2 + H → *NNH. However, in this catalyst system, the PDS of the NRR process at each metal active site is not the first hydrogenation step, but *NNH + H → *NNH2, or *N + H → *NH (Fig. 20b–d). Co-Cu and Ni-Ru have strong surface hydrogenation abilities, with a preference for adsorbing *H at these sites (Fig. 20e). Hydrogenation at the t-Fe site is more likely to occur. When *H is well-covered at these sites, adjacent t-Fe activates N2 and reduces it to NH3 (Fig. 20f). The electrocatalytic reduction of nitrate ions to ammonia (NO3RR) entails a complex process that includes nine proton transfers, eight electron transfers, and the formation of multiple intermediate species [248,249]. Zhi et al. [250] utilized a phase engineering approach to introduce intermetallic nanoparticles onto bulk FeCoNiAlTi HEA, resulting in nanostructured HEA (n-HEA) with enhanced electrochemically active surface area and improved charge transfer efficiency, thereby enabling catalysts with multiple active sites to exploit synergistic effects for achieving high selectivity (Fig. 20g and h). The resulting n-HEA provides enhanced electrochemical NO3RR performance in terms of NH3 yield (0.52 mg h−1 cm−2) and FE (95.23%) at −0.5 V (Fig. 20i). In the above cases, different metals can play different roles and act synergistically, resulting in outstanding NRR/NO3RR performance. Carbon and nitrogen cycle reaction processes (CO2RR, NRR, NO3RR) are the focus of the current energy and environmental crisis (carbon dioxide emissions and nitrate pollution), and these two types of reactions have complex multi-step reaction processes and produce many different intermediates [251,252]. HEA has more active sites due to its complex multi-component, so it is more suitable for complex catalytic reactions [16,77]. Considering that some of the intermediates involved in the above-mentioned reactions are trace, short lived, and sensitive to the electrolyte reaction microenvironment, it greatly increases the difficulty of understanding the reaction path. Therefore, it is necessary to develop more advanced in-situ or operational techniques to capture the reaction intermediates in time and clarify the evolution process of the substrate. 3.7 Alcohol oxidation reaction (AOR) As renewable energy technologies grow, electrolytic hydrogen production is becoming a sustainable and efficient method for creating pure hydrogen [253,254]. However, due to the slow kinetics of its anodic OER, its commercialization is still limited by high cost and high energy consumption. Researchers have reduced energy consumption by combining hydrogen evolution with the oxidation of small organic molecules, which also produces valuable chemicals for industry [255–257]. On the other hand, compared with hydrogen fuel cells, direct alcohol fuel cells have advantages in terms of safety, storage, and transportation, and have greater potential for sustainable power supplies [258–260]. Recent studies have shown that some HEA electrocatalysts are more stable, selective, and active than traditional alloys [261,262]. Lai et al. [12] obtained uniform-size ultrafine Pt18Ni26Fe15Co14Cu27 HEA NPs by using a low-temperature oil phase synthesis strategy under atmospheric pressure. They demonstrated the mass activity of such HEA catalyst in the alkaline methanol oxidation reaction (MOR) to be as high as 15.4 A mg−1 Pt (Fig. 21 a). DFT calculations confirmed multiple active sites on the HEA surface that promote intermediate transformation. Synergistic effects between elements improve CH3OH adsorption and proton/electron transfer (Fig. 21b–d). In addition, compared with MOR, the free energy barrier and activation energy of the rate-determining step corresponding to the CO poisoning pathway are higher, which effectively inhibits the formation and poisoning of CO (Fig. 21e). In another study, Wang et al. [263] proposed a surface strain strategy to regulate the electronic structure of HEAs for efficient MOR. HEAs with a FCC structure were prepared by thermal reduction, which induced strain by changing the sintering temperature. Fig. 21(f and g) shows that the compressive strain of HEA-700 obtained at 700 °C is higher than that of HEA-400 obtained at 400 °C. The area-specific activity and mass-specific activity of HEA-700 are much higher than HEA-400 and commercial Pt/C catalysts. The enhancement of MOR activity is attributed to the shortening of Pt–Pt bond distance in HEA-700 due to compressive strain (Fig. 21h). At the same time, compressive strain and downward shift of d-band center improved CO tolerance (Fig. 21i and j). Huang et al. [151] synthesized a series of HEAs with different dimensional structures (0D–3D). Among them, PdPtCuPbBi HEA with a 2D ultrathin nanoring structure showed excellent mass activity for ethanol oxidation reaction (EOR), with the maximum mass activity of 18.21 A mg−1 Pd+Pt and excellent stability (Fig. 22 a and b). The theoretical calculation shows that the synergistic effect between the components of the catalyst and the high configuration entropy enhances the adsorption of *OH and weakens the adsorption of *CO, which may be the reason for the remarkable improvement of the catalyst performance. The inherent characteristics of HEAs, such as lattice distortion and synergistic effect, can also promote selective and active glycerol oxidation reaction (GOR). Wen et al. [152] prepared a self-supported electrode based on CoNiCuMnMo HEA NPs (CoNiCuMnMo-NPs/CC). In Fig. 22(c and d), dislocations are observed in the (−2 0 2) and (0 −2 2) lattice planes and the defects cause large deformation of small NPs, which in turn generates surface tension, thereby improving catalytic performance. The electrode showed excellent GOR electrocatalytic performance in alkaline electrolyte, and the current density reached 10 mA cm−2 at 1.25 V (Fig. 22e). Over a wide potential range, the FE to formate exceeds 90%, at the same time with good stability (Fig. 22f and g). In an asymmetric-electrolyte electrolyzer cell with 0.1 M glycerol (Fig. 22h), the catalyst can achieve 10 mA cm−2 by applying only 0.55 V voltage, which is much lower than the traditional OER/HER system (Fig. 22i). The analysis of several electrocatalytic reactions presented above demonstrates the intricate nature of enhancing the electrocatalytic performance of HEAs, which involves the synergistic interplay of multiple factors. This paper provides a summary of the four core effects of HEAs on electrocatalytic reactions, focusing on their activity, stability, and selectivity. Activity: In contrast to traditional single metal, binary, and ternary alloys, the high entropy effect of HEAs provides a significant electron and component regulation space. This allows the catalyst to achieve the appropriate adsorption energy for reactants and key intermediates, thereby enhancing the catalytic efficiency of the active site. Furthermore, lattice distortion effects may lead to surface defects or unsaturated coordination environments, exposing additional active sites [264]. Stability: On the one hand, the HEA catalysts exhibit high stability in challenging environments, such as high temperatures and strong acid or alkali conditions, due to the slow diffusion effect. On the other hand, the formation of a single solid solution phase hinders the creation of potential differences between various components, thereby enhancing the corrosion resistance of HEAs [52]. Selectivity: The synergy between multiple metals of HEAs (“cocktail” effect) provides multiple types of adsorption sites, showing advantages in multi-step reactions (e.g. CO2RR, NRR, and NO3RR). However, for catalytic reactions where there is a competitive reaction, for example, acidic CO2RR will introduce a competitively favorable HER, thereby reducing the efficiency of CO2RR, and the coexistence of multiple competing adsorption sites will result in undesirable reaction selectivity [122]. At present, how to selectively regulate adsorption energy is still a big challenge. 4 Summary and prospects The research progress of HEAs as catalysts for electrocatalytic reactions in recent years was reviewed, mainly focusing on the preparation strategy of HEAs adapted to electrocatalytic application. Catalytic reactions usually involve multi-steps and multi-intermediates, and the multi-active sites of HEAs just meet this need. The four core effects of HEAs can optimize catalyst activity, and selectivity, and improve stability, potentially at a reduced cost. The appearance of HEAs breaks the design principle of traditional alloys and the possible composition of many elements and complex atomic arrangements. On the one hand, HEAs broaden the adjustment window of catalyst preparation and modification. On the other hand, the synthesis of HEA catalysts with controlled properties poses major challenges. Also, the precise characterization and understanding of HEAs have a significant difficulty. In general, the in-depth understanding of HEAs synthesis and regulation mechanism is still in its infancy. Here, we list the most prominent problems and some potential solutions (Fig. 23 ). (1) Develop a new model system With the increase of different kinds of catalytic sites and the interference of the “cocktail” effect, it is very time-consuming to understand the specific active site of HEAs by either DFT calculations or experimentally. HEAs have a huge number of different possible sites making it unfeasible the designing and engineering of optimized HEAs based on the current trial-and-error strategy. The combination of advanced high-throughput screening, computationally directed design, and machine learning is expected to effectively accelerate the search for novel high-performance HEA electrocatalysts. For example, Singh's team [265] used a trained neural network model directly to quickly predict the adsorption energy at tens of thousands of different sites, resulting in a map of the adsorption energy distribution and a deeper understanding of HEAs. Zhao et al. [266] developed a machine-learning model and used it in HEAs. The test results show that the prediction speed of the atomic graph attention model is 40,000 times faster than that of first-principles calculations. Moreover, the model is universal and can meet the advanced material design in different scenarios. (2) Introduce advanced characterization and descriptors Despite all the advantages of HEAs, there are some unexplained effects and some simplistic and vague interpretations of structure–activity relationships. HEAs have high catalytic activity and stability due to the synergistic effect of multiple metal sites. However, the coexistence of multiple competing reactive sites will also reduce the selectivity of the reaction, especially since the preferential regulation of rate-limiting steps cannot be guaranteed. It is well known that the diffusion rate of atoms is greatly related to the grain size of the material. However, it is not clear whether the diffusion rate of atoms is still consistent with the sluggish diffusion effect when the HEAs size is sub-nanometer or nanocluster. It is also unclear clear how to combine HEAs with other regulatory strategies, and how to quantitatively characterize the four effects. To overcome these limitations, advanced in-situ characterization techniques (near-atmospheric XPS, in-situ TEM, etc.) are needed to establish the accurate correlation of structural properties and to understand the structure–activity relationship. For example, Mu et al. [267] revealed the synergistic effect of multiple cations at the atomic and nanoscale by conducting valence state analysis and microcosmic synthesis characterization of metal elements, thus elucidating the “cocktail” effect. In electrocatalysts, descriptors are important indicators that relate physicochemical interactions and catalytic performance in electrochemical processes. How to extract accurate descriptors for the four effects of HEAs is helpful for in-depth exploration of catalytic behavior, reasonable explanation of catalytic phenomena, and selection of target catalysts. For example, Gao et al. [9] proposed new descriptors based on tight-binding and Friedel models to quantitatively characterize the local chemical environment and magnetic moments of HEAs. (3) Apply HEAs to the industry Research on HEAs as electrocatalysts has experienced a surge in activity over the past decade, yet it remains in a nascent stage of development. Presently, the majority of research endeavors are focused on exploring small-scale synthesis techniques and conducting elemental combination screenings in laboratory environments [79,268]. Nevertheless, it is pertinent to question the feasibility of these methodologies for facilitating the mass production of nanostructured HEAs. The investigation of synthesis methodologies conducive to industrial-scale manufacturing carries substantial practical implications. From the application point of view, HEA electrocatalysts must be tested under industrial-relevant electrocatalytic conditions. In this direction, the development of HEAs suitable for industrial high currents could be the next breakthrough. For example, the economic competitiveness of hydrogen production from water splitting is still limited when compared to steam methane reforming and coal gasification. This is primarily attributed to the low efficiency and durability of catalysts under high currents, leading to elevated power and catalyst expenses. To address this issue, the development of a functional structure integrated catalytic electrode with exceptional activity and stability under ultra-high current density represents the most direct approach to reducing the cost of water electrolysis. Yang et al. [269] fabricated a highly efficient and long-lasting large-area alloy electrode, containing a low amount of platinum, through laser writing on a commercially available laser welding machine. The resulting electrode exhibited exceptional alkaline HER activity and stability, as demonstrated by its ability to sustain a current density of 1 A cm−2. HEA foams assisted with 3D printing can be directly prepared for industrial electrocatalysis, or HEA powder can be sprayed on traditional nickel foam to prepare self-supporting electrodes. Foam materials with 3D structures can expose more active sites, provide higher mechanical stability, and suit better large-scale applications. HEAs exhibit a distinctive multi-site synergistic catalysis mechanism, rendering it potential in heterogeneous catalytic reactions such as photoelectrocatalysis [270], bioelectrocatalysis [271] and bifunctional catalysis involving anodic oxidation and cathode reduction [272] The exceptional mechanical properties and corrosion resistance exhibited by HEAs make them suitable for utilization in electrochemical corrosion protection [273]. On one hand, they can serve as a protective coating for internal metal materials, while on the other hand, they can function as a sacrificial material, leveraging the potential difference to impede the electrochemical corrosion reaction of the safeguarded metal material. The economic and environmental benefits of HEAs are crucial for their sustainable utilization in large-scale industrial applications. For example, Fabijanic et al. [274] successfully synthesized HEAs from metal scrap, demonstrating comparable microstructure and mechanical properties to commercially available HEAs. This study highlights the potential for significant cost reduction in HEA production through strategic selection of appropriate metal scrap sources. In another study, Meza et al. [275] illustrated the viability of this approach through the extraction of metals from recycled electronic waste for the production of HEAs with superior performance. Future research efforts are centered on environmental conservation, necessitating the reduction of toxic element content in HEAs and prevention of material dissolution during the reaction process. Guoliang Gao received his Ph.D. degree from the East China Normal University in 2022. He is presently working in Suzhou University. His research interests are water electrolysis and small molecule oxidation. Yangyang Yu is currently pursuing a bachelor's degree at Suzhou University. His main research direction is the design and synthesis of electrocatalysts. Guang Zhu received his Ph.D. in 2012 from East China Normal University. He was a postdoctoral fellow at Northwestern University, USA, and later joined Suzhou University, China, as an professor. His research interests include the synthesis and properties of nanomaterials and their applications in the energy and environmental fields. Bowen Sun is currently pursuing a master’s degree at the School of Nanoscience and Materials Engineering, Henan University, under the supervision of Professor Zixu Sun, whose main research interests are the synthesis of covalent organic frameworks and the application of lithium-sulfur batteries. Ren He is currently pursuing his Ph.D. degree at Barcelona University (Spain) and under the supervision of Prof. Andreu Cabot at the Catalonia Institute for Energy Research. Prior to this, he obtained the Master degree from He Bei University (China, Baoding) and Adelaide University (Australia, Adelaide). His current research mainly focuses on the design and synthesis of high entropy alloy and compounds, with the application of oxygen catalysis, zinc air batteries and lithium sulfur batteries. Andreu Cabot is ICREA Research Professor at the Catalonia Institute for Energy Research (IREC), Spain. He received his PhD from the University of Barcelona in 2003. From 2004 to 2007, he worked as a postdoctoral researcher in Prof. A. Paul Alivisatos group at the University of California at Berkeley and the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. His main research interests include the design and engineering of nanoparticles and nanomaterials, the characterization of their functional properties, their use for the manufacturing of scaffolds and electrodes using 3D printing technologies, and their application in energy conversion and storage. He has published close to 300 scientific articles and is a co-author of 5 patents. Zixu Sun is currently a professor in School of Nanoscience and Materials Engineering at Henan University, China. He received his Ph.D. degree in Materials Science at Ningbo Institute of Materials Technology & Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2016. He worked at Nanyang Technological University (NTU), Singapore, from 2016 to 2021. His research interests are lithium/sodium/potassium ion batteries, metal–sulfur batteries, and electrocatalysis.

coredata.dc:description: Compared to traditional pure metals or alloys based on just one principal element, high entropy alloys (HEAs) exhibit notable structural and physical characteristics, drawing significant attention. While significant advancements have been made in the synthesis and utilization of HEAs, there is a lack of comprehensive understanding and systematic approach towards the rational design of electrocatalysts. This review begins by introducing the fundamental principles and impacts of HEAs, followed by an overview of traditional and emerging synthesis techniques; in particular, we categorize and critically analyze approaches. Subsequently, a detailed examination of the advancements and comparative performance of HEAs in specific electrocatalytic reactions is presented. The paper concludes by outlining the current challenges and opportunities associated with HEAs catalysts, along with offering personal insights on potential future developments.
